ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I, of course, learned much about the theories of political economy. My favorite lectures were those on the competitive market equilibrium, the Nash bargaining theory, and equality of opportunity. But perhaps more importantly, I feel that learned something about how to think like a political economist. I learned how to use simplified models to visualize and explain complex ideas and concepts. And I learned that if you delved deep enough, even the simplest of social and political phenomena can have fascinating implications.
Mathematical approaches to socio-economic and political issues.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I really enjoyed the take-home format of the exams. It gave me a chance to thoroughly think about some concepts/problems. The lecture notes online are also helpful. It would be more helpful if some concepts appeared in the problem sets can be discussed in class first.

There are no weaknesses I would like to report. In terms of the strengths of the course, I felt there was a balanced mix of theoretical and practical elements, and just the right amount of mathematical work. The problem sets were generally thought-provoking, and were quite effective in reinforcing what we learned in class. The take-home exams, I thought, were an excellent ideathough I spent much more time on them than I would have spent studying for an in-class exam. I realized that it was one thing to learn about different models and theories in class; it was an entirely different challenge to put all that knowledge together and address specific social/political problems.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would for anyone who is interested in the field of political economy. It is a great introductory course to think through basic concepts and build the foundation to move further.
